code.displayName: CHIEF COMPLAINT AND REASON FOR VISIT

section.title: CHIEF COMPLAINT(S) AND REASON FOR VISIT
section.text: Back Pain and worsening of stomach cramps.

text.paragraph: Father (deceased)

This is a 56-year-old white male who went to the emergency room with sudden onset of severe left flank and left lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with gross hematuria. The patient had a CT stone profile which showed no evidence of renal calculi. He was referred for urologic evaluation.

When seen in our office, the patient continued to have mild left flank pain and no difficultly voiding. Urinalysis showed 1+ occult blood. Intravenous pyelogram was done which demonstrated a low-lying malrotated right kidney. There was no evidence of renal or ureteral calculi or hydronephrosis. Urine cytology was negative for malignant cells. The patient subsequently had a CT renal scan with contrast. This showed what appeared to be an infarction of an area of the lower pole of the left kidney. It was suggested that a renal MRI be done for further delineation of this problem. He had a right kidney which was malrotated but was otherwise normal. The patient is admitted at this time for complete urologic evaluation.
In 1996, the patient experienced a minor stroke, which caused temporary paralysis in his left arm. He was monitored in hospital for three weeks and recovered.

3 years ago, he was diagnosed as lupus carrier. Since the diagnosis, he has been taking Warfarin and expects to maintain Warfarin therapy for life. His condition has exacerbated a series of endotheliopathies, predisposing him to retinal microvascular occlusion.
2 weeks prior to his current hospital admission, he was also diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia. He is currently taking Lipitol to manage this.

act.text: Possible flu-like symptoms for three days.
